Authors: Hidayat D., Abdurachman E., Elidjen, Hutagaol Y.
Title: Empirical studies on knowledge creation and performance: A literature review
Source title: Proceedings of 2020 International Conference on Information Management and Technology, ICIMTech 2020
Affiliations: BINUS Entrepreneurship Center, Bina Nusantara University, Management Department, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; BINUS Business School Doctor of Research in Management, Bina Nusantara University, Management Department, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; BINUS Business School Doctor of Research in Management, Bina Nusantara University, Management Department, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Bina Nusantara University, Faculty of Economics Communication, International Accounting and Finance Program, Accounting Departement, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Hidayat, D., BINUS Entrepreneurship Center, Bina Nusantara University, Management Department, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Abdurachman, E., BINUS Business School Doctor of Research in Management, Bina Nusantara University, Management Department, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Elidjen, BINUS Business School Doctor of Research in Management, Bina Nusantara University, Management Department, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Hutagaol, Y., Bina Nusantara University, Faculty of Economics Communication, International Accounting and Finance Program, Accounting Departement, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Knowledge creation has been an important factor in order to improve firm's competitive strategy. A lot of studies have been done to understand the effects of knowledge creation on performance. Although there are a lot of empirical research related with knowledge creation, but the review on the research direction of knowledge creation is still limited. This paper gives insight on knowledge creation and performance, analyzes the empirical research, and provide future direction. The method used for this research is literature review by collecting and analyzing empirical Scopus articles from 2014 until 2020 by using two keywords: 'knowledge creation' AND performance also SECI AND performance. Result shows that research in knowledge creation has been done in various countries and industries, with the term knowledge creation process and SECI indicators widely used to represent knowledge creation. More research is still needed to show how knowledge creation affects performance. © 2020 IEEE.
Author Keywords: Knowledge creation; Knowledge creation process; Literature review; Performance
Index Keywords: Competitive strategy; Empirical research; Empirical studies; Knowledge creations; Literature reviews; Information management

Authors: Hidayat D., Pangaribuan C.H., Putra O., Suci A.
Title: Business model innovation on smes: A literature review
Source title: International Journal of Advanced Science and Technology
Affiliations: BINUS Entrepreneurship Center, Management Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Faculty of Business, Sampoerna University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Management Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Hidayat, D., BINUS Entrepreneurship Center, Management Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Pangaribuan, C.H., Faculty of Business, Sampoerna University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Putra, O., Management Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Suci, A., BINUS Entrepreneurship Center, Management Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: Business model innovation (BMI) has been a popular topic to understand how a company can get its competitive advantages. Despite previous articles on BMI on large companies, the research on business model innovation on small medium enterprises (SMEs) remains limited. This paper gives insights on BMI for SMEs, analyzes the methodology and unit analysis, and provides future directions. The method used for this research is literature review by collecting and analyzing Scopus articles from 2014 until 2020. This paper then conducted a review on the driving factors of BMI, the influence of external factors, as well as the tools and strategic ways for improvement. © 2020 SERSC.
Author Keywords: Business Model Innovation; Literature Review; SMEs

Authors: Pangaribuan C.H., Wijaya F.H., Djamil A.B., Hi-Dayat D., Putra O.P.B.
Title: An analysis on the importance of motivation to transfer learning in VUCA environments
Affiliations: Sampoerna University, Indonesia; Department of Management, BINUS Business School Undergraduate Program, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Pangaribuan, C.H., Sampoerna University, Indonesia; Wijaya, F.H., Sampoerna University, Indonesia; Djamil, A.B., Sampoerna University, Indonesia; Hi-Dayat, D., Department of Management, BINUS Business School Undergraduate Program, Indonesia; Putra, O.P.B., Department of Management, BINUS Business School Undergraduate Program, Indonesia
Abstract: In this VUCA world, much can be achieved when one is open to learning. The purpose of this study is to analyze the impact of organizational learning culture, employee commitment, and job satisfaction towards motivation to transfer learning. The data are collected by distributing 200 questionnaires for employees working in Jakarta area. The method used to do the analysis is by using a multilinear regression. Based on the result, organizational learning culture and job satisfaction had significant impacts to motivation to transfer learning. Meanwhile, employee commitment does not have significant effect on motivation to transfer learning, however, it has an impact on the gender, age, and length of work. © 2020 by the authors; licensee Growing Science, Canada
Author Keywords: Employee Commitment; Job Satisfaction; Motivation to Transfer Learning; Organizational Learning Culture; VUCA

Authors: Fernando E., Surjandy S., Meyliana M., Wijadja H.A., Hidayat D., Kusumaningtyas A.W., Heryatno R.
Title: Factors influencing the intention to use technology services to implement self-service technology case study: Situation pandemic Covid-19
Source title: Advances in Science, Technology and Engineering Systems
Affiliations: School of Information Systems, Information Systems Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; BINUS Entrepreneurship Center, Management Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; BINUS Entrepreneurship Center, Global Employability and Entrepreneurship, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Fernando, E., School of Information Systems, Information Systems Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Surjandy, S., School of Information Systems, Information Systems Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Meyliana, M., School of Information Systems, Information Systems Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Wijadja, H.A., School of Information Systems, Information Systems Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Hidayat, D., BINUS Entrepreneurship Center, Management Department, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Kusumaningtyas, A.W., BINUS Entrepreneurship Center, Global Employability and Entrepreneurship, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia; Heryatno, R., BINUS Entrepreneurship Center, Global Employability and Entrepreneurship, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, 11480, Indonesia
Abstract: This study aims to analyze a person's intention in using self-service technology (SST) services during the pandemic COVID-19. Where this time, raising problems one of the social distancing that affects a service provided, especially on services that use technology that applies SST. This study develops from previous research where the customer has satisfaction in using SST services. Still, this use does not know a person intention to use SST services, so it is necessary to develop with several factors the adoption of technology, namely influence that can make a person intention to use. The research framework of this research consists of several factors and indicators, namely efficiency (4 indicators), Reliability (4 indicators), security (3 indicators), Convenience (3 indicators), Ease of use (4 indicators). This study uses an online survey with google form for users of self-service technology services in 5 major cities in Indonesia. Dissemination of the survey for three months, and the obtained were 100 respondents valid. This research conducts testing using Smarpls v3.0. The results of this study found two factors that influence perceived usefulness, namely: efficiency and reliability, and found three factors that did not have an impact, namely Security factors, Convenience Factors, Perceived Ease of use, and Service Trust do not have an impact on perceived usefulness. This result is a very interesting finding because during the period pandemic COVID-19. These factors are no longer the top priority in the use of SST services and do not affect who intention to use a technology service. Thus, it can be concluded that whose intention at a certain level of the problem will prioritize the reliability and efficiency of the system for service. This factor can be the focus of the company in developing systems that adopt Self-service technology. © 2020 ASTES Publishers. All rights reserved.
